text.p: Funscape Corp has agreed to acquire Oilex Inc in exchange for seven million shares, investor Allen Burditt II told Reuters.
He also said this transaction will be followed by the acquisition of 800 oil wells from Rife Oil for additional shares.
A formal announcement of the transactions is expected in about an hour.
After both mergers, Burditt said, he will hold about 2.5 million Funscape shares, roughly 15 percent of the 13.2 million expected to be outstanding.
Burditt said another 2.5 million shares will be held by Sawyer Adecor, while Rife Oil will hold about 2 million shares and Oliver Timmons one million.
Burditt said Funscape has agreed to exchange one share for each 5.1 outstanding Oilex shares.
At Funscape's Tuesday closing price of $4.25 a share, the proposal values Oilex stock at $0.83 per share. The stock closed Tuesday at 21/32.
Burditt said the merger is expected to be a tax-free transaction and pointed out that the new company will also acquire Oilex's $6.5 million tax loss carryforward.
Funscape is the owner of Oil Retrieval Systems Inc, the maker of the portable swabbing units used by Oilex to produce shallow, low volume oil wells.
Oilex held 20 percent of Oil Retrieval before that company was acquired by Funscape for 2.5 million shares last month.

The Oilex stake was acquired in January as part of an agreement giving the company a 30-day preferential first right of refusal to all portable swabbing units Oil Retrieval built on speculations, without prior orders.
That agreement also gave Oil Retrieval a 25 percent interest in Oilex's Revilo unit in exchange for providing a minimum of three portable swabbing units in 1997.

Funscape's annoucement of the acquisition quoted its president, M.O. Rife III as saying, "The combination of the companies with their technology, producing properties and combined oil and gas manufacturing and management expertise allows for a fully integrated synergistic application of resources."
The merger will create a company elgible to trade on Nasdaq's small caps market, Burditt said.

Oilex director Ricard Clark said in the "worst case" the company should have production of 5,000 barrels per day from its swabbing operations resulting in revenues from that source alone of $20 million a year.
Clark said he has accepted an invitation to serve on the merged company's board.
He told Reuters the company has found a new facility that will let it double production of the portable swabbing units by year end -- to a pace of six per month.
After the merger transaction is completed, Burditt said, the company will be "ready to get a line of credit to fund infill drilling" in the fields it controls.
The company now has 1,400 infill drilling sites.
Clark noted this is a very low risk form of oil drilling which increases the number of wells in a developed area to the maximum allowed by local regulations.
He said there are 10,000 abandoned wells in Texas alone which could be produced with portable swabbing technology.

On a daily basis, or as wells dictate, the portable swabbing unit lowers, by cable, swabbing tools inside the casing of a well bore to a depth where fluid is encountered and pulls (swabs) 4 to 5 barrels of oil, gas and water back to the surface through a housing on the unit and delivers the fluids to the unit's 40 or 70 barrel holding tank.
Oilex said this procedure takes about ten minutes.
To accomplish the same by conventional means takes up to 24 hours, it points out.
Once the new company is swabbing 1,000 wells per day, Clark continued, its cost will be less than $4 per barrel.

In the future, Burditt said, the company will look at leasing the portable swabbing units to other operator for $4,000 to $5,000 per month and providing operating expertise in return for a piece of the lease being operated.
"I do want (the company) to be an acquisition target a year and a half out," Burditt concluded.
